ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Formation and crystallization kinetics of Nd–Fe–B-based bulk amorphous alloy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Magnetism Key Laboratory of Zhejiang Province

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
In order to improve the glass-forming ability (GFA) of Nd–Fe–B ternary alloys to obtain fully amorphous bulk Nd–Fe–B-based alloy, the effects of Mo and Y doping on GFA of the alloys were investigated. It was found that the substitution of Mo for Fe and Y for Nd enhanced the GFA of the Nd–Y–Fe–Mo–B alloys. It was also revealed that the GFA of the samples was optimized by 4 at.% Mo doping and increased with the Y content. The fully amorphous structures were all formed in the Nd

BMG was investigated in isothermal situation. The Avrami exponent n determined by JAM plot is lower than 2.5, implying that the crystallization is mainly governed by a growth of particles with decreasing nucleation rate.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Traditionally, Nd–Fe–B permanent magnets are prepared either by powdering and sintering [1] or melt spinning and bond molding [2–4]. Several steps are required to obtain a final product with optimal magnetic properties. In 2000, Zhang and Inoue [5, 6] first reported that fully dense Nd
$$_{2}$$
2
Fe
$$_{14}$$
14
B/(Fe
$$_{3}$$
3
B/
$$\alpha $$
α
-Fe) nanocomposite permanent magnet could be produced by crystallization of Fe
$$_{76}$$
76
Co
$$_{9.4}$$
9.4
Nd
$$_{3.1}$$
3.1
Dy
$$_{0.5}$$
0.5
B
$$_{20}$$
20
bulk metallic glasses (BMGs). Since then, the method prepared fully dense bulk nanocomposite rare-earth magnets from directly devitrification of Nd–Fe–B-based BMGs has been developed. This approach simplifies production process of the permanent magnets, minimizes contamination and avoids the dilution of magnetic phase by polymer [7, 8]. Some investigations on the preparation, thermal and magnetic properties of bulk Nd–Fe–B-based magnets have been done [5–9]. However, bulk amorphous alloys with large size and excellent hard magnetic properties after crystallization could not be obtained due to limited glass-forming ability (GFA) and low rare earth content of these Nd–Fe–B-based alloys. Furthermore, crystallization kinetics of Nd–Fe–B-based BMGs have not been fully understood yet.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
The alloy ingots with nominal compositions of Nd
$$_{6-\textit{x}}$$
6 - x
Y
$$_{\textit{x}}$$
x
Fe
$$_{72-\textit{y}}$$
72 - y
Mo
$$_{\textit{y}}$$
y
B
$$_{22}$$
22
(x, y
$$=$$
=
0–5) were obtained by arc melting mixtures of Nd, Fe, Y, Mo with a purity of more than 99.9 % and pre-alloyed FeB in argon atmosphere. Rods in 1.5 and 4.0 mm diameter were produced by injecting the melt into a copper mold. The as-cast rods were sealed in a quartz tube under argon atmosphere and then isothermally annealed at 650–800
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C for 10 min. Ribbons were prepared by melt spinning at a wheel speed of 35 m/s.

The thermal properties of the as-cast ribbons were investigated by using a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) at a heating rate of 40 K/min. Isothermal DSC experiments were carried out using different constant heating rates. The samples were heated up to the annealing temperature at a heating rate of 20 K/min and then held at this temperature to follow the crystallization until completion. The phase composition was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Microstructure investigations of cross section of the samples were carried out by a Hitachi 4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). The specimens for SEM were cut, ground and polished with standard metallurgical procedures, and then eroded by 5 % of a 1:1 mixture of nitric acid and sulfuric acid. A Tecnai F20 TEM has been used to observe the microstructure. The samples prepared for TEM observation were cut into 3 mm discs and subsequently ion-milled.

To gain a further insight into the effect of Mo doping on GFA, DSC curves for melt-spun amorphous ribbons were studied to compare supercooled liquid region
$$\Delta T_x $$
Δ
T x
(
$$=T_\mathrm{g}-T_{x})$$
=
T g
-
T x
)
defined by the difference between the glass transition temperature (
$$T_\mathrm{g})$$
T g
)
and the crystallization temperature (
$$T_{x})$$
T x
)
of the all alloys, as shown in Fig. 2. It is seen that
$$\Delta T_x $$
Δ
T x
of the alloy with y = 4 has a maximum value, indicating the GFA is enhanced by substitution of 4 at.% Mo for Fe, which is consistent with the XRD result obtained in Fig. 1. Mo substitution effect on GFA in the Nd–Fe–B system might be attributed to the atomic arrangement and the heats of mixing [10]. Atomic-size mismatch may increase the degree of dense random packed structure and viscosity of liquids, which improves GFA. Large negative mixing enthalpies enhance the interactions between the components and restrain atomic rearrangement on a long range scale for crystallization. First, the atomic radii of Nd, Mo, Fe, B are 0.164, 0.136, 0.128, 0.078 nm, respectively. The Mo atoms make the present combination of atomic sizes more sequential, which increases the degree of dense random packed structure and viscosity of liquids. Second, the heats of mixing of Nd–B, Fe–B, and Mo–B are –49, –26 and –34 kJ/mol, respectively, which indicates the existence of strong cohesive forces between them and restrain atomic rearrangement for crystallization [12]. GFA is largely enhanced by the addition of Mo element.
Fig. 2
DSC curves for the as-cast Nd

$$_{72-\textit{y}}$$

) alloys

According to the backbone (or network-like) structure in Fe-based BMGs suggested by Ponnambalam and Poon [13], in the present alloy system, large Mo and Nd atoms refractory atoms (with total content of about 10 at.%) most likely occupy central positions and small B atoms locate at interstitial positions, while Fe atoms with medium atomic radii fill up the residual space. The reasonable distribution of atomic size can stabilize and strengthen amorphous structure, increasing the melt viscosity and improve the GFA.

However, when the Mo content is larger than 4 at.% (i.e. total content of large Mo and Nd atoms refractory atoms exceeds 10 at.%), the reinforced backbone structure with high GFA could be destroyed. In addition, heat of mixing between Mo and Nd element is positive (26 kJ/mol), average Mo–Nd atomic distance with the Mo content in the alloys becomes shorter and could cause deterioration of GFA [10].

In order to further improve the GFA of Nd–Fe–B–Mo alloy to obtain fully amorphous bulk Nd–Fe–B-based alloy, the Y element is doped. The effect of Y doping on GFA of Nd–Fe–B–Mo alloy is discussed in our previous paper [14]. It was found that the
$$\Delta T_x $$
Δ
T x
values increase remarkably with the content of Y in the Nd

(x = 0–5), indicating that the GFA is enhanced with the increasing of the Y content. In this paper, the effect of Y doping on GFA of Nd–Fe–B–Mo alloy is investigated further. Glassy alloy with high reduced glass transition temperature
$$T_\mathrm{rg}=T_\mathrm{g}$$
T rg

(x = 0, 5) alloys with various yttrium contents, obtained by a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) at a heating rate of 40 K/min, are plotted in Fig. 3. The liquidus temperature
$$T_\mathrm{l}$$
T l
is indicated by arrows in the inset. It is obviously found that the Y addition decreases the liquidus temperature
$$T_\mathrm{l}$$
T l
. The values of reduced glass transition temperature
$$T_\mathrm{rg}$$
T rg
from Fig. 3 are 0.790 and 0.817 for
$$x=0$$
x = 0
and 5, respectively. It suggests that the alloy with
$$x=5$$
x = 5
has better GFA. Moreover, with no yttrium addition, the alloy exhibits a non-eutectic melting, followed by two endothermic peaks. With addition of 5 at.% Y, the alloy shows an eutectic melting, indicating that the GFA is enhanced by the 5 at.% Y addition. The Y addition satisfies the three empirical rules for achieving high GFA [16]: (1) multicomponent alloy systems consisting of more than three constituent elements; (2) significantly different atomic size ratios above 12 % among the main constituent elements; (3) negative heats of a mixing among their elements. The addition of Y causes a more sequential change in atomic size in the order of
$$Nd>Y>Mo>Fe>>B$$
N d > Y > M o > F e > > B
as well as the generation of atomic pairs with relatively large negative heats of mixing [17].

The results reveal that the inflection point is the phenomenon of chemical short-range ordering, which has also been confirmed by TEM image, shown as Fig. 6. The short-range ordering clusters of 2–3 nm in size can be observed in the TEM image. The phenomenon was reported in former studies [19–21].

During an isothermal annealing, transformation kinetics from the amorphous state to the crystalline state can occur, and the phase transformation is characterized by the crystallized volume fraction,
$$x(t)$$
x ( t )
. This evolution can be described by the JMA model and the following equation [22]: 1
$$\begin{aligned} x(t)=1-\exp [-k(t)^n] \end{aligned}$$
x
( t )
= 1 - exp [ - k
( t )
n
]
where
$$n$$
n
is the kinetics exponent (Avrami exponent), which reflects both the crystallization mechanism and the dimensionality of the crystallization process;
$$t$$
t
is the annealing time;
$$K$$
K
is the reaction rate constant (
$$K$$
K
depends on the annealing temperature).

Taking the double logarithm of Eq. (1), the following expression is deduced [23]: 2
$$\begin{aligned} \ln \left[ {-\ln (1-x)} \right] =n\ln k+n\ln (t) \end{aligned}$$
ln
- ln ( 1 - x )
= n ln k + n ln
( t )
According to the diffusion-controlled growth theory [24], n
$$=$$
=
1.5 means that growth of particles occurs with a nucleation rate close to zero;
$$1.5 \,\,{\le }\,\, n 2.5 \,\,{\le }\,$$
1.5
≤
n 2.5
≤
indicates a growth of particles with decreasing nucleation rate, n
$$=$$
=
2.5 reflects growth of particles with constant nucleation rate, and n
$$\ge $$
≥
2.5 corresponds to the growth of small particles with an increasing nucleation rate [25, 26].

By least square fitting of
$$\ln [-\ln (1-x)]$$
ln [ - ln ( 1 - x ) ]
versus
$$\ln (t)$$
ln ( t )
, the value of kinetic exponent
$$n$$
n
is determined in the Fig.8. The n value of Nd
$$_{3}$$

$$_{3}$$

$$_{68}$$

Mo
$$_{4}$$

C, which implies that the crystallization of Nd
$$_{3}$$

Y
$$_{3}$$
3
Fe
$$_{68}$$
68
Mo
$$_{4}$$
4
B
$$_{22}$$
22
bulk metallic glass is governed by a growth of particles with decreasing nucleation rate. It is deduced that enormous number of short-range ordering clusters formed at the inflection temperature act as overcritical nuclei. The growth of the overcritical nuclei and formation of new nuclei require simultaneous rearrangement of different species of atoms. Due to the dense randomly packed atomic configuration of multi-component amorphous alloy, diffusion of atoms is difficult, which retards the nucleation and growth, leading to a decreasing nucleation rate [27].

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para:
The effects of Mo and Y doping on GFA of the alloys were investigated with Differential scanning calorimetry and X-ray diffraction investigations. It was revealed that the GFA of the samples optimized by 4 at.% Mo doping and increased with the Y content. Based on the result of enhanced GFA by the Mo and Y element doping, fully amorphous structures were eventually formed in the Nd
$$_{6-\textit{x}}$$

$$_{3}$$

alloy rod exhibited an uniform distribution of grains, and a coercivity of 364.1 kA/m has been obtained. The crystallization behavior of Nd
$$_{3}$$

$$_{3}$$

Fe
$$_{68}$$
68
Mo
$$_{4}$$
4
B
$$_{22}$$
22
BMGs was investigated by the JMA model. The Avrami exponent n is lower than 2.5, implying that the crystallization is mainly governed by a growth of particles with decreasing nucleation rate. It can be deduced that short-range ordering clusters formed at the inflection temperature act as crystallization nuclei.
